content.raw:
Alfredo, the disk was my local problem \(downloading too many docker images and not realizing, that the SSD is not too big\), fixed \(deleting old images\).

I can confirm that the latest \(today\) docker handles IMU at 50Hz:

`0:01:00.028855 (13.6 -4.5 0.0) [('acc', 1664), ('pose2d', 1661), ('rot', 1664), ('scan', 346), ('sim_time_sec', 34)]`

so no problem with the current latest `cloudsim_sim` - is the same used on AWS?
content.html:
Alfredo, the disk was my local problem (downloading too many docker images and not realizing, that the SSD is not too big), fixed (deleting old images).

I can confirm that the latest (today) docker handles IMU at 50Hz:

0:01:00.028855 (13.6 -4.5 0.0) [('acc', 1664), ('pose2d', 1661), ('rot', 1664), ('scan', 346), ('sim_time_sec', 34)]

so no problem with the current latest cloudsim_sim - is the same used on AWS?

content.raw:
Martin, I’m glad that the problem and thank you for confirming and letting us know.  
  
I also ran out of space one time and every other week I run the commands below to delete old or obsolete docker containers.  

```
$ docker ps -a

$ docker rm -f [CONTAINER_ID]
```

I believe the production Cloudsim environment has the latest version you're now running locally, but I’m going to confirm with @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0}
content.html:
Martin, I’m glad that the problem and thank you for confirming and letting us know.

I also ran out of space one time and every other week I run the commands below to delete old or obsolete docker containers. 

$ docker ps -a

$ docker rm -f [CONTAINER_ID]

I believe the production Cloudsim environment has the latest version you're now running locally, but I’m going to confirm with @Nate Koenig

content.raw: Yes, cloudsim has the latest version of our software.
content.html: Yes, cloudsim has the latest version of our software.

content.raw:
I believe the “triangle input” messages are something simulator based and should not be an issue with preventing your solution from running \(I see them too on my sample submissions that work\).

What do you expect “2 minutes \+ subt\_seed artifact report” to do?  Does the content of the other logs indicate nothing happened as well?  Have you watched the Ignition Gazebo log file back yet?

`ign gazebo --playback <folder_containing_logs>`
content.html:

content.raw:
There is an effort on-going to get more log files from the competitor’s instances returned.  Right now that includes ROS logs.

That replay command I shared will work with the log files from a Cloudsim run and will show you what the vehicle actually did in simulation.  It’s not as good as actual command line feedback but you can see if you vehicle did anything.
content.html:
There is an effort on-going to get more log files from the competitor’s instances returned. Right now that includes ROS logs.

That replay command I shared will work with the log files from a Cloudsim run and will show you what the vehicle actually did in simulation. It’s not as good as actual command line feedback but you can see if you vehicle did anything.

content.raw: I just replayed the log file for 15de7ba1-e825-4f39-b8d2-34f427e8416c, and it looks like the robot did not move.
content.html: I just replayed the log file for 15de7ba1-e825-4f39-b8d2-34f427e8416c, and it looks like the robot did not move.

I agree that is currently minor issue \(in particular if you do not plan to change the simulation docker image\).

content.raw: The docker hash is different on cloudsim than dockerhub. We could try recording the version information of the osrf/subt repo.
content.html: The docker hash is different on cloudsim than dockerhub. We could try recording the version information of the osrf/subt repo.

content.raw:
> The docker hash is different on cloudsim than dockerhub. We could try recording the version information of the [osrf/subt](#!/osrf/subt) repo.

Do I understand correctly that cloudsim does not run the docker images we all are running? Otherwise I do not see how the image hashes could be different. Can this be unified? There are way to many knobs that need to be all pointed in the right direction for the simulation to work \(still working on #261\). Removing any of them \(like this difference\) is greatly appreciated.
content.html:
The docker hash is different on cloudsim than dockerhub. We could try recording the version information of the osrf/subt repo.

Do I understand correctly that cloudsim does not run the docker images we all are running? Otherwise I do not see how the image hashes could be different. Can this be unified? There are way to many knobs that need to be all pointed in the right direction for the simulation to work (still working on #261). Removing any of them (like this difference) is greatly appreciated.

content.raw: Cloudsim does not run the same docker image as those hosted on Dockerhub. This is mandatory because cloudsim has to host private (secret) competition worlds. As far as I'm aware, there is no way to make the public and private docker image identical.
content.html: Cloudsim does not run the same docker image as those hosted on Dockerhub. This is mandatory because cloudsim has to host private (secret) competition worlds. As far as I'm aware, there is no way to make the public and private docker image identical.

content.raw: But this is true during only a very limited time when you are evaluating the solutions, isn’t it? So from now until, let’s say, July we can be running the same thing as cloudsim. That would help to lower the number of variables we are dealing with.
content.html: But this is true during only a very limited time when you are evaluating the solutions, isn’t it? So from now until, let’s say, July we can be running the same thing as cloudsim. That would help to lower the number of variables we are dealing with.
